history.content:
As a general friendly piece of advice for attempting a CS major at Berkeley, I would recommend taking each semester one step at a time. The classes you will be taking the first couple of semesters will likely be classes that don't pertain much to anything for graduate school and will be focused mostly on setting you up with a solid CS foundation while "weeding out" students per the GPA cutoff. Basically what I'm saying is don't think so much about graduate school programs while you still haven't guaranteed that you will be a CS major.

With that said, it's always good to do what you're doing and plan ahead for your future. I know there are talks of implementing a Data Science major, which I would guess would be your "backup" major if you can't make the CS GPA cutoff. Since the major has not yet officially been introduced, the prereqs are not set, but I'm fairly certain Data 8 will be one of them. I don't know the status of that class in terms of enrollment capacity but if it's filled up for this semester I'd recommend you take that either in the Spring or next Fall. Regardless of whether or not it is a prereq for Data Science, and regardless of whether or not you end up declaring CS, it's probably a good class to have if your goal is to study data science as a subject while you're here.

Hopefully that helped. TL;DR, pay attention to any announcements regarding the Data Science major as either a potential fallback (or even double major), take your next four years one semester at a time, and enjoy the ride. Go bears :)

children.subject: Data 8 is definitely a great class to take first semester. Not a lot of work and very fun, with great teaching. You could then take data100 either in the spring or next fall, depending on when you complete the rest of the prereqs! (math 54/EE16A, CS61A)
